moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3
comment: The thematic plan.  White intends Bg5, which threatens Bxf6 and would force a weakness.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6
comment: Supposed mistake number one. 13...Rc8 should be better.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3
comment: This is still completely in line with the classical plan.  After ...g6 the white bishop switches to a more active diagonal.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Ba2 Nd5 18. Ne4 Rc7 19. Ne5 Bf8
comment: Supposed mistake number two.  Now black gets into trouble because of the f6-square.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Ba2 Nd5 18. Ne4 Rc7 19. Ne5 Bf8 20. Bg5 Be7 21. Bxe7 Rexe7
comment: Supposed mistake number three.  Black blatantly ignores the weak dark squares and especially f6.  21...Qxe7 was the obvious move.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Ba2 Nd5 18. Ne4 Rc7 19. Ne5 Bf8 20. Bg5 Be7 21. Bxe7 Rexe7 22. Bxd5
comment: Starting a very tempting attack.  The next five moves or so usually get a flurry of exclams, and they fully deserve them, if the attack works...

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Ba2 Nd5 18. Ne4 Rc7 19. Ne5 Bf8 20. Bg5 Be7 21. Bxe7 Rexe7 22. Bxd5 exd5 23. Nf6+ Kg7 24. Qh3 h5 25. Nxh5+

1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Ba2 Nd5 18. Ne4 Rc7 19. Ne5 Bf8 20. Bg5 Be7 21. Bxe7 Rexe7 22. Bxd5 exd5 23. Nf6+ Kg7 24. Qh3 h5 25. Nxh5+ gxh5 26. Rd3 Qh8 27. Rg3+ Kf8 28. Rg5 Re6
comment: Now white wins smoothly.  The question posed by my computer is this: how to win after 28...h4.  Moreover, how to equalize??  Well, white has played all of the right moves and, further, black has two pieces marooned on the queenside while his king is exposed.  Therefore, at first I naturally assumed that white had something.  But I can't find it!  The computers are very powerful advocates for concrete variations over generalities, and they tenaciously find resources for the material grabber.  Chess thought is already being re-evaluated in many variations (like the Poisoned Pawn, where white can no longer just "say" he has compensation), and this may be one more example.

moves: 1. c4 c5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. e3 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. d4 cxd4 7. exd4 Be7 8. Bd3 Nc6 9. O-O O-O 10. Re1 Nf6 11. a3 b6 12. Bc2 Bb7 13. Qd3 g6 14. Bh6 Re8 15. Rad1 Rc8 16. Bb3 Na5 17. Rxh5+
comment: Now the endgame is very favorable to white. Firstly, because of the three kingside passers, and secondly, the Rs have lots of open lines.
